Introductory Essay on the Provenance of the Early Manuscripts
Most of the early manuscripts share at least one major thread of ownership and preservation. It is convenient, therefore, to organize these threads in an introductory essay for central reference. At the opposite end of the scale in the archive, the Apparatus Pages for each individual work and manuscript (see Plan of the Archive) contain provenance information specific to the object in question, while also linking the reader to this essay and/or to one of the notes tracing a major thread of provenance.
This essay provides an overview of the provenance of the early manuscripts, including what is known about when they presumably were kept together at Ruskin's three homes, Herne Hill, Denmark Hill, and Brantwood. Following Ruskin's death, clusters of manuscripts were carried along separate threads of provenance, which are traced in the following associated notes on sales and individual collectors:

The Sales Following the Brantwood years, the provenance of most of the early manuscripts is accounted for in the two Sotheby’s sales of Ruskin manuscripts removed from the house, held respectively on 24 July 1930 () and 18 May 1931 (). Most remaining early manuscripts were probably sold during the final dispersal sale at Brantwood itself on 28, 30, and 31 July 1931 ().

The Allen sale to the Huntington, however, appears to be solidly established as consisting of manuscripts of the 1850s and afterwards, not letters or earlier manuscripts.
